message.content:
Below is a worked‐through example of how one can “read” the two images and then pick out and order the correct blocks from the dictionary.

-------------------------------------------------------
1)  ANALYSIS OF THE MAIN (TARGET) IMAGE
-------------------------------------------------------
There are two separate little “builds” in the scene:

• LEFT BUILD (5 blocks, 2 layers tall)  
  – Bottom Layer (3 blocks): A vertical blue “pillar” sandwiched between two orange triangular wedges (one on the left, one on the right).  
  – Top Layer (2 blocks): A green rectangular block bridging across the top of the blue pillar, with a smaller orange triangular block perched on it.  

• RIGHT BUILD (8 blocks, effectively 4 layers tall)  
  – Layer 1 (front “feet” plus cubes behind): Two yellow half‐cylinders at the front, and behind them a green cube (left) plus a blue cube (right).  
  – Layer 2: One wide yellow rectangular block bridging across the green‑and‑blue cubes.  
  – Layer 3: One red arch block (the large red piece with a half‐circle cutout).  
  – Layer 4+: Another green rectangular block bridging across the top of the arch, with an orange triangular block capping it.  

In total, the scene uses 13 blocks (5 in the smaller left structure + 8 in the larger right structure).

-------------------------------------------------------
2)  SELECTING THE REQUIRED DICTIONARY BLOCKS
-------------------------------------------------------
Matching color, shape, and orientation (no re‐orientations allowed), the structure can be made with the following indices:

A)  Left Build (5 blocks total)  
  1.  #14 (orange triangular wedge) – left base wedge  
  2.  #3  (blue cube)              – center “pillar”  
  3.  #16 (orange triangular wedge) – right base wedge  
  4.  #5  (green rectangular)      – green bridging piece on top of pillar  
  5.  #13 (orange triangular wedge) – small orange “roof” on very top  

B)  Right Build (8 blocks total)  
  6.   #9  (yellow half‐cylinder) – left foot  
  7.   #9  (yellow half‐cylinder) – right foot  
  8.   #4  (green cube)           – bottom‐layer cube (left)  
  9.   #3  (blue cube)            – bottom‐layer cube (right)  
 10.   #7  (yellow rectangular)   – wide yellow “belt” bridging the cubes  
 11.   #1  (red arch)             – the large red arch block  
 12.   #5  (green rectangular)    – green bridging piece on top of arch  
 13.   #13 (orange triangular)    – small orange roof/hat at the top  

Notice that some indices appear more than once (for example, #9 for both feet, #3 in each build, etc.).

-------------------------------------------------------
3)  RECOMMENDED ASSEMBLY ORDER
-------------------------------------------------------
A simple bottom‐to‐top assembly order might be:

{
  Step1:  Move block with index 14   // Left orange base of small build
  Step2:  Move block with index 3    // Blue cube “pillar” of small build
  Step3:  Move block with index 16   // Right orange base of small build
  Step4:  Move block with index 5    // Green rectangular across the top
  Step5:  Move block with index 13   // Small orange triangle “roof”
  
  Step6:  Move block with index 9    // Left yellow half‐cylinder (foot)
  Step7:  Move block with index 9    // Right yellow half‐cylinder (foot)
  Step8:  Move block with index 4    // Green cube behind left foot
  Step9:  Move block with index 3    // Blue cube behind right foot
  Step10: Move block with index 7    // Wide yellow rectangular bridging
  Step11: Move block with index 1    // Red arch
  Step12: Move block with index 5    // Green rectangular on top of arch
  Step13: Move block with index 13   // Top orange triangular cap
}

Following those steps (and using each block in the orientation shown in the dictionary photograph), you will exactly reproduce both the small left structure and the taller right structure in the target image.
